Award.AwardTitle: Asymmetric Synthesis of Alkaloids Enabled by Novel Methodology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Rodrigo B. Andrade. Professor Andrade is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at Temple University. He is developing new chemical reactions to quickly build complex nitrogen-containing molecules. The overarching goal is to maximize the efficiency by which complex, three-dimensional molecules are prepared by using new reagents and reactions discovered in his laboratory. Such an approach reduces the time, energy, and cost associated with synthesizing complex molecules composed of carbon and nitrogen atoms. Many such molecules are biologically active, and so they can be employed as molecular probes to better understand biochemical pathways or as therapeutics to be used in medicine. Beyond the training of undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, the broader impacts of this project touch the fields of organic chemistry (e.g., total synthesis, synthetic methodology), chemical biology, molecular biology, biochemistry, and medicine.

N-Sulfinyl metallodienamines (NSMDs) have emerged as powerful asymmetric synthons for chemical synthesis. The focus of this project is to determine both the mechanism and scope of reactions using acyclic NSMDs with a variety of electrophiles, which logically builds from previous efforts on arene-fused congeners. Specifically, in Aim 1 the researchers are studying the scope of the reactions of acyclic NSMDs with electrophilic olefins to afford cycloadducts through a Domino Michael/Mannich (formal Diels-Alder) process. In Aim 2, the research group is applying optimal reaction conditions determined from Aim 1 toward the step-efficient, asymmetric total syntheses of complex Iboga alkaloids (+)-catharanthine, (+)-coronaridine, and (+)-ibogamine. In Aim 3, the research students are systematically investigating the reactions of NSMDs with aldehydes (vinylogous aldol) and imines (vinylogous Mannich). In Aim 4, researchers are probing the reactions of NSMDs with electrophilic oxygen and nitrogen sources to access alpha-functionalized N-sulfinyl imines, which can be further modified to access chiral building blocks for organic synthesis. Computer modeling is used in all mechanistic analyses. Professor Andrade has demonstrated a strong commitment to the inclusion of undergraduates, particularly from underrepresented groups, in his research activities.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
A. Intellectual Merit

            The thrust of the funded project was to explore novel methods that rapidly allow for the preparation (chemical synthesis) of complex molecules prepared by Nature termed natural products (NPs). The project targeted a unique class of NPs that possess nitrogen called alkaloids. While NPs serve as benchmarks of efficiency, synthetic methodology can be employed to procure fine chemicals (building blocks), pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals among others.  During the project period the following NPs were prepared:  epi-condyfoline, 16-methoxytabersonine, 16-hydroxytabersonine, pachysiphine, lochnericine, and the dimeric alkaloid, melodinine K.

The funding of this project resulted in the development of selective reactions that allow for the preparation of C-C, C-N, and C-O bonds. Subsequent application of these reaction to the synthesis of NPs served to test the limits of methodologies discovered and developed during the funded project period. Support from the NSF was mission critical to both the study and application of these reactions in the arena of natural products synthesis.

 

B. Broader Impacts

            The fields of organic and medicinal chemistry were advanced through the introduction of novel ways of preparing chiral (handed) molecules and their application to the chemical synthesis of complex, bioactive NPs (i.e., asymmetric synthesis). Half of our medicines are derived from NPs. Accordingly, the procurement of NPs by chemical synthesis, an overarching goal during the funded project period, allows for their subsequent evaluation and usage as medicines.  The training of our next generation of STEM scholars is of enormous consequence. The project enabled the training of both graduate and undergraduate students to think critically and creatively by engaging in NP synthesis, which present unique logic puzzles to practitioners. Temple University, located in Philadelphia, is one of the Nation's most diverse urban campuses. The project has permitted the participation of women and underrepresented groups to further diverse our STEM population.

 

C. Summary of Findings

            Over the funded project period, the Andrade laboratory was able to develop new reactions for the rapid and efficient assembly of complex, bioactive NPs for subsequent biological evaluation. The significance of our findings is underscored by the critical role NPs command in medicine. As a result of our methods, bioactive NPs and congeners thereof can be prepared in a more efficient manner in terms of time, cost and effort (TCE). The TCE of any chemical synthesis is ultimately felt by consumers and the general public; accordingly, the greater the TCE, the greater the financial burden is on the consumer.  Innovative approaches to chemical synthesis are critical for driving down TCE. The discovery of new reactions that access critical C-C, C-N, and C-O bonds has enabled the efficient synthesis of the following NP targets: epi-condyfoline, 16-methoxytabersonine, 16-hydroxytabersonine, pachysiphine, lochnericine, and the dimeric alkaloid, melodinine K.

            The training of the next generation of scientists to tackle the existential threats facing humanity is fundamental to the health of the Nation. Chemical synthesis of complex NPs offers tremendous opportunities for the development of critical and creative thinking; therefore, the funded project successfully trained a cohort of undergraduate and graduate students, some from underrepresented groups, who will be prepared intellectually for the challenges confronting the US and the World.


Last Modified: 08/07/2020
Modified by: Rodrigo B Andrade
